Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2009 12:19PM sahalie wrote: Robin.  This should be a big time talk between you and your breast surgeon according to your path reports and tests.    No easy decision for some.  My surgeon sat with me for three hours on our very first meeting going over everything.  I was so grateful to him.  I had already made up my mind to have the bilateral like some have stated above.  I just didn't want the other bomb to drop down the road through the years.  I was totally at peace with my decision and still am. I trusted my surgeon completely.  He was recommended as the best in my area so I felt great about that.  You want people taking care of you and your body that you have complete confidence in.  I also had the BRCA testing and it came out negative. This is the time you do for you what you feel in your heart and soul and with the expertise of your doctors to make this decision.  I wish you the best of everything.  Sahalie

Posts.Content: Jul 18, 2008 10:18AM sahalie wrote: Hi Tweeker. I also had a bilateral mastectomy.  My left breast was the one with the cancer but I knew from the beginning that I wanted both breasts removed just so I wouldn't have to deal something happening in my right breast down the road. Funny thing is I tested negative with the BRCA test. I pray my daughter doesn't have to deal with breast cancer in the future. I did not have reconstruction and love being flat chested.  No Bras.  No constraints. Best of luck to you.  Sahalie

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2008 09:25AM sahalie wrote: Me too. Fatigue is the ball and chain I drag around with me on a daily basis. I have tried everything.  It is so nice to know we are in this together.  As it turned out I did have hypothyroidism with one gland bullying the other three and causing my calcium levels to get very high.   I had to have surgery a year ago March to have the gland removed.  Didn't help in the least with the fatigue.  It's still here but at least my calcium levels are normal.  I have to take a daily supplement of OS-Cal.  I just had one of my six month check ups and had the usual blood work up before the appt. and things all look normal so I have no clue why the monstrous fatigue keeps hanging around.  SherriG.  Thank you for what you shared about what your onc told you.  That makes the most sense I've heard through this journey.
Posts.Title: Still have the fatigue after 2 years. Mary-Lou Molly2013

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2008 09:44PM sahalie wrote: My hypothyroidism symptoms were extreme fatigue and to the moon high levels of calcium found with my blood tests. There is also HyPERthyroidism that is dealt with by medication. HyPOthyroidism was one of my four glands was enlarged and sucking the energy right out of me. I do feel a difference since the surgery March 2007 but I am still fatigued. You can find excellent information about both from your doctors.  Mine sent me immediately to the correct doctor who in turn arranged for the surgery immediately.  I stayed one night and was home the next day by 1PM.   You can't see any scar in my neck. Good luck everyone.
Posts.Title: Still have the fatigue after 2 years. Mary-Lou Molly2013

Posts.Content: Aug 19, 2008 10:20AM - edited Aug 19, 2008 10:24AM by sahalie Please ask and discuss with your doctors about thyroid issues etc. Some of us that have posted have first hand experience with Hypo and Hyper Thyroidism and others have not. Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2009 03:37PM sahalie wrote: Wow you are so young to have to deal with this.  I'm so sorry.  Do you have a history in your family of breast cancer?  I knew from the moment of dx I wanted "both" removed.  My surgeon was totally supportive and we moved forward.  It was my left breast that had the cancer.  I was also in the midst of an unbelievable situation at home with my dh on life support.  So I knew I couldn't deal with the other shoe dropping down the line.  I didn't have reconstruction and absolutely love the free feeling on my chest.  No bras.  Just soft silk or cotton tanks under blouses and I actually found a perfect swim suit for all my swimming. It has a pleated square front across the top so I don't have to fill it with anything.  I had the BRCA testing done after the surgery and came out negative but my own personal opinion on that is this disease is a cruddola shoot and no matter what the BRCA test shows ~ no one is immune to getting this hideous disease.   I wish you every best.  Talk to your docs a lot.  Take tons of notes.  Call him/her for anything on your mind.  Do what is right for you and your situation.   All the best.  I wish you/us didn't have to deal with this at any age. I had IDC found only during surgery for DCIS.  XOXO.  Sahalie

Posts.Content: Dec 14, 2007 03:55PM sahalie wrote: Bimmer, I am sending your words to the local papers here.  Thank you for giving us the permission to do so. Your post is outstanding! In my paper this morning is a huge article stating how with using the oncotype testing it is known now that certain women were less likely to die or have a relapse if given a less harsh drug than Adriamycin, a mainstay of treatment for decades.  It states the gene test can help predict whether some women need chemo at all even among those whose cancer has spread to their lymph nodes, which typically brings full treatment now. The oncotype DX test measures the activity of 21 genes and gives a score to predict risk of recurrence.  This test is for estrogen positive women and whose hormone driven cancer had spread to the lymph nodes.  I remember reading this info in my clinic's reading material but now it's official due to the statement by the National Cancer Institute and the test's maker, Genomic Health and Duke University's cancer expert it states the test would give valuable information to guide treatment for patients in the future. Your information and analogy needs to be in every paper in every town to bring it home to men and women that this year alone according to statistics more than 178,000 new cases of breast cancer will be expected in 2008. Keep up the good work Bimmer.   Please give Diane a gentle hug from me.  Tell her the grape vines are bare now and frost is covering them making the rows look like glistening strings of shimmering magical vine ornaments.

Posts.Title: I am ready to quit.... mrs_X_Sunneedazee lovinmomma

Posts.Content: May 6, 2009 10:10PM sahalie wrote: LAnna.   You asked what my dx etc. was. I was initially dx with DCIS in 2006.  It was during my bilateral mastectomy surgery that my surgeon found I actually had some invasive cells.  I had already opted for the bilateral mastectomy.  I had a mm tumor, clean margins,  a SNB with no node involvement.  I am triple negative.  I took chemo.  A/C and am checked every six months with blood work before each check up.  We are each different in healing but for me it was one of the easier surgeries to heal from.  The drains were a drag but came out after two weeks.  I could do anything but you know the funny thing is how numb areas feel.  Still do.  I miss my breasts but love my life more.  I did not reconstruct.  You have to wait to shower according to your doctor then keep the steri strips dry until they come off.  I was told to not pull them off.  I used Tylenol for pain so you can tell it wasn't too bad.  It all depends on each circumstance and situation at home.  My surgeon told me to call him for any reason whatsoever.  I did and would encourage you to do the same.  I would write down things so when I actually got him on the phone I was able to address all my concerns and questions.  I wish you all good luck.  It's a good thing to ask for and accept help when friends and family offer meals and help the first few days.  That way you can rest when you come home from the hospital. I was Stage 1.  Grade 2.  Triple Negative.

Posts.Content: Jun 12, 2008 07:03PM sahalie wrote: Hi, I also had a bilateral mast with no node involvement but. . . I didn't have expanders put in so I'm thinking that has to be the pain. I was sore but used only Tylenol and felt amazingly good for what I had just been through. Over five hour surgery. The drains were something else though. The BC side did drain more. I kept a schedule of amounts per my bsurgeon request. Sometimes the area would begin to hurt like a tight pinch so I would "milk the tiny tube" which would take care of a small clot and then I would feel much better. Someone that has gone through the expanders will come along to help you with that area I'm sure. My drains came out after two weeks. Best of luck.  You will feel better in no time.

Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2008 11:43AM sahalie wrote: Hello Vivian. I had my bilateral mastectomy in April 2006. When I had my first meeting with my surgeon after dx. I knew I wanted a bilateral mast. so I wouldn't have to deal with another Kaboom down the road. So he granted my wish. I had NO reconstruction and have been so much happier ever since. What a free feeling. I wear no prosthesis.  Just comfortable tees, tanks etc. My husband passed suddenly three weeks after my bilat. mast. at a young age. He was the love of my life so will not marry again so I figure what the heck. I love being flat chested.  I save money on not buying bras. I hated bras anyway.  So restricting. It's funny though.  Even two years from surgery every now and then I get the feeling I need to pull on my bra strap. Good luck with your decision. I am extremely happy with mine. Sahalie

Posts.Content: May 16, 2009 10:23AM sahalie wrote: I watched it with awe for Farrah and her journey.  The fortitude she used to continue the filming from beginning to now in bed full time.  When she showed her head I began to cry.  Not for the loss of her beautiful curls but for her undeniable strength and courage to unveil herself to everyone.  It was her purpose to show the hideous sides of cancer and the nightmare it puts us all through what ever our type of cancer.  I will watch it again.  I hope and pray her son straightens himself out so he can be by her side.  She adores and loves him so very much. I think we all have friends and family who have been targeted by the gamut of cancers.  I know I have.  Farrah's story last night really touched home.  And how wonderful to see the love and devotion of her soul mate Ryan and her best friend Alana and all her friends staying around her through it all. Most of all her Dad.  Precious father who has lost his wife and other daughter.  Heart breaking but what a life lesson this woman has shared in so many avenues of dreadful horrible cancer. We must keep fighting hard as nails for the cure.
